Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Phylogeny and Floral Evolution of Malpighiaceae
Award.AbstractNarration:
Malpighiaceae is a large, ancestrally New World flowering plant family that has dispersed independently to the Old World on seven separate occasions during the past ~60 Myr. The distinctive floral morphology of New World species includes oil glands, which provide pollinators with rewards other than pollen or nectar. The flowers that produce nutrient oils also have a unique bilateral floral symmetry that has been conserved for millions of years via interactions with specialist oil-bee pollinators. All Old World species, in contrast, have regular flowers with radial symmetry. This project will investigate diversification in plant-pollinator mutualism within the family by producing a morphological and molecular phylogeny of ~1300 Malpighiaceae species. In addition, the researchers will investigate the early genetic and developmental basis of bilateral symmetry in the New World species and establish the genetic and developmental basis for the convergent evolution of regular flower phenotypes in the Old World species.

This study of this large and ecologically important group of tropical plants will serve as a model to understand whether similar genetic and developmental mechanisms are driving the parallel evolution of flower shape. The project will train a post-doctoral researcher, undergraduate and graduate students, including individuals from under-represented groups. Research results will be disseminated through an online monograph on the Malphigiaceae, and through targeted short-courses for elementary and high school students within Cambridge, MA.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Malpighiaceae are a large pantropical flowering plant clade that originated in the New World (NW) with seven subclades independently dispersing to the Old World (OW) during the past ~60 Myr. The distinctive floral morphology of NW species, including oil glands and a unique bilateral floral symmetry, is highly conserved and has been maintained for millions of years via interactions with their specialist oil-bee pollinators. Malpighiaceae thus offer an exceptional opportunity to examine the genetic and developmental mechanisms underlying convergent evolution related to plant-pollinator interactions. The Project Aims were to: 1) produce a worldwide phylogeny of ~1300 Malpighiaceae including morphological scoring to investigate diversification in this plant-pollinator mutualism (Davis lab, lead); 2) determine the early genetic and developmental basis of bilateral symmetry in their stereotyped flowers (Zhang lab, lead); 3) and establish the genetic and developmental basis for the convergent evolution of floral phenotypes (Zhang lab, lead).

In Aim 1 the Davis lab investigated the Neotropical biogeography of Malpighiaceae, and identified an astonishing 33 migrations from South American clades that helped to establish the seasonally dry tropical forest biome of Mexico. Furthermore, dispersal rates between South America and Mexico exhibit a significant six-fold increase during the mid-Miocene (~23.9 Myr) strongly suggesting the availability of Central America as an important region for Neotropical plant migration. These results establish a much older time for the availability of the Isthmus of Panama as a major corridor of plant migration and suggest that barriers to migration across the Isthmus might be more related to ecological, rather than geological barriers. Such an hypothesis might explain the divergent times of migration for different clades of organisms (including plants versus animals). Additionally, this project established the complex biogeographic history of the aquatic plant clade Elatinaceae, the sister group to Malpighiaceace. This demonstrated that unlike most aquatic angiosperms investigated to date, Elatinaceae exhibit a very deep evolutionary history, which is consistent with ancient patterns of vicariance (versus solely recent dispersal as has been proposed for aquatic angiosperms). This also established that Malpighiaceae may be older than previously reported, and possibility originated on western Gondwana (i.e., the united land masses of modern Africa and South America).

We also demonstrated that the extraordinarily uniform floral morphology of the diverse Neotropical plant clade Malpighiaceae has been actively maintained by specialized oil-bee pollinators for millions of years. Specifically, these results show clear evidence for accelerated rates of floral morphological evolution in the nine Malpighiaceae clades that have lost their tight association with specialized oil-bee pollinators. Thus, long-term morphological stasis in this case is not maintained by internal developmental/genetic constraints, but instead by ongoing natural selection by their mutualist pollinators. 

Salary funds provided by this grant were used to hire a Postdoctoral Fellow at Harvard University and train five postdoctoral fellows and four graduate students. Our results were distributed on our interactive website for Malpighiaceae to make our results available to the broader community. These results were also distributed in numerous talks at national and international meetings, university seminars, and in public venues.
